revisions.rev:
[[Image:Pneumococcal Awareness Council of Experts logo.jpg|frame|right]] âThe '''Pneumococcal Awareness Council of Experts (PACE)''' is a project of the [[Sabin Vaccine Institute]] and is composed of global experts in [[infectious disease]]s and [[vaccine]]s. Established in December 2006, The Council seeks to raise awareness among policymakers and aims to secure global commitments to prevent [[pneumococcal disease]], a leading infectious killer of children and adults worldwide.<ref name="WHO Pneumococcal Vaccines">World Health Organization, [http://www.who.int/vaccines/en/pneumococcus.shtml/ "Pneumococcal vaccines"]</ref> The Council works in collaboration and partnership with countries, [[Non-governmental organization|NGOs]], academia and industry.
==Council Members== PACE is made up of 21 global experts on [[infectious disease]]s and [[vaccine]]s from 17 countries around the world. The Council is chaired by [[Ciro de Quadros|Ciro A. de Quadros]], Executive Vice President of the [[Sabin Vaccine Institute]] and [[Orin Levine]], Executive Director of PneumoADIP<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.pneumoadip.org/ |title=PneumoADIP}}</ref> at the [[Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health]].

Saha | [[Dhaka Shishu Hospital]] | [[Bangladesh]] |- | JosÃ© Ignacio Santos | [[National Autonomous University of Mexico]] | [[Mexico]] |- | Mathuram Santosham | [[Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health|AVI, Johns Hopkins University Bloomberg School of Public Health]] | [[United States|USA]] |- | Samba Sow | Center for Vaccine Development<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://medschool.umaryland.edu/cvd/facilities_mali.asp |title=Mali Center for Vaccine Development}}</ref> | [[Mali]] |- | Fred Were | Kenya Paediatric Association<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kenyapaediatric.org/ |title=Kenya Paediatric Association}}</ref> | [[Kenya]] |- | Cynthia Whitney | [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|U.S. Centers for Diseases Control and Prevention]] | [[United States|USA]] |- | Yong-Hong Yang | Beijing Childrenâs Hospital | [[China]] |}
==Events== PACE has hosted and participated in a number of events worldwide to help raise awareness about [[Streptococcus pneumoniae|pneumococcal disease]].
On May 4, 2007, the launch of PACE was announced at a press conference in [[Washington, D.C.]] At the event, PACE gave its first annual Global Leadership Award.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sabin.org/advocacy-education/pace/pace-global-leadership-award/ |title=PACE Global Leadership Award}}</ref> The Global Leadership Award is given annually by PACE to recognize an individual, organization or country that has championed [[pneumococcal disease]] prevention and made a significant contribution towards policies that advance the introduction of [[pneumococcal conjugate vaccine]]s. PACE Global Leadership Award recipients include: Dr. Thomas Cherian, who has helped accelerate the surveillance of [[pneumonia]] throughout the developing world and contributed to research on the global [[pneumococcal]] [[disease burden]]. The Health Minister of [[Rwanda]] â the first country in [[Africa]] to introduce [[pneumococcal conjugate vaccine]]s; and the Health Minister of [[Costa Rica]] â the first country in [[Latin America]] to implement a nationwide vaccination program.<ref name="sabin.org">{{Cite web|url=http://sabin.org/pressroom/releases/2007/05/07/global-health-experts-unite-combat-worlds-leading-vaccine-preventable/ |title=Global Health Experts Unite to Combat the Worldâs Leading Vaccine-Preventable Killer}}</ref>
On November 20, 2007, PACE's European launch took place in [[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]] with representatives from professional societies, PACE member Pavla Krizova, and the Czech Ministry of Health in attendance.<ref name="sabin.org"/>
On February 15, 2008, PACE held a press event during the 3rd Regional Pneumococcal Symposium<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sabin.org/events/third-regional-pneumococcal-symposium/ |title=3rd Regional Pneumococcal Symposium}}</ref> in [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] to call upon policy leaders in [[Turkey]] and the region to assure access to [[pneumococcal vaccines]] and to support the expansion of health systems to deliver them and monitor their impact.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sabin.org/pressroom/releases/2008/10/27/leading-health-experts-urge-turkish-global-policy-leaders-take-action-/ |title=Leading Health Experts Urge Turkish, Global Policy Leaders To Take Action Against Pneumococcal Disease}}</ref>
On June 10, 2008, PACE along with the [[Sabin Vaccine Institute]], PATH and PneumoADIP, participated in the 6th International Symposium on Pneumococci and Pneumococcal Diseases (ISPPD-6)<ref name="International Symposium on Pneumococci">The Lancet (2009). [http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(09)61204-6/fulltext/ "Burden of disease caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae in children younger than 5 years: global estimates"]</ref> in [[Reykjavik]], [[Iceland]]. PACE issued a Global Call to Action on Pneumococcal Disease Prevention,<ref name="PACE Call to Action">{{Cite web|url=http://sabin.org/advocacy-education/pace/call-to-action/ |title=PACE Call to Action}}</ref> urging governments to take steps to make financing available for access to [[pneumococcal vaccines]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sabin.org/pressroom/releases/2008/10/27/health-experts-call-global-leaders-ensure-access-life-saving-pneumococ/ |title=Health Experts Call on Global Leaders to Ensure Access to Life-Saving Pneumococcal Vaccines}}</ref>
On October 24, 2008, over 100 professional medical societies, institutions and organizations from around the world had signed PACEâs Global Call to Action to urge governments, donors and industry to ensure access to [[pneumococcal vaccines]]. [[Rwanda]] announced that they would be one of the first two countries to introduce the [[pneumococcal vaccine]] into its national immunization program in the spring of 2009.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sabin.org/pressroom/releases/2008/10/24/medical-societies-join-forces-assure-equal-access-life-saving-vaccines/ |title=Medical Societies Join Forces to Assure Equal Access to Life-Saving Vaccines}}</ref>
On January 31, 2009 PACE and the Hib Initiative<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.hibaction.org/ |title=Hib Initiative}}</ref> hosted ''Childhood Pneumonia and Meningitis: Recent Advances''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sabin.org/events/childhood-pneumonia-meningitis-recent-advances/ |title=Childhood Pneumonia and Meningitis: Recent Advances}}</ref> at [[Aga Khan University]] in [[Karachi]], [[Pakistan]]. The event, brought together stakeholders in child health from [[Pakistan]], including health professionals, representatives from the Ministry of Health and EPI officials. Event leaders, PACE Co-chair [[Ciro de Quadros|Dr. Ciro de Quadros]] and PACE member Dr. Zulfiqar Bhutta, highlighted the role of advocacy in combating childhood [[pneumonia]] and [[meningitis]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sabin.org/events/childhood-pneumonia-meningitis-recent-advances/ |title=Sabin Childhood Pneumonia">"Childhood Pneumonia & Meningitis: Recent Advances}}</ref>
On March 3, 2009, PACE, in conjunction with the [[Sabin Vaccine Institute]], PneumoADIP and the [[World Health Organization|WHO]], hosted a media briefing at the Sabin Vaccine Institute's 4th Regional Pneumococcal Symposium<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sabin.org/events/fourth-regional-pneumococcal-symposium/ |title=Sabin Vaccine Institute's 4th Regional Pneumococcal Symposium}}</ref> in [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]], at which PACE released two new studies, ''Sequelae Due to Bacterial Meningitis among African Children: A Systematic Literature Review'',<ref name="Sequelae Due to Bacterial Meningitis among African Children">Ramakrishnan, Meenakshi, et al. (2009). [http://www.biomedcentral.com/1741-7015/7/47/abstract/ "Sequelae due to bacterial meningitis among African children: a systematic literature review"], BMC Medicine.</ref> and ''Bacterial Infections in Persons with Sickle Cell Disease: A Review of Data from Africa with a Focus on Pneumococcal Disease''.<ref name="Bacterial Infections in Persons with Sickle Cell Disease">[http://www.sabin.org/pressroom/releases/2010/04/28/vaccines-preventing-pneumococcal-disease-provide-vital-protection-afri "Bacterial Infections in Persons with Sickle Cell Disease: A Review of Data from Africa with a Focus on Pneumococcal Disease"]</ref> The event also sought to highlight [[South Africa]]'s introduction of the [[pneumococcal vaccine]], with support from the [[GAVI Alliance]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sabin.org/pressroom/releases/2009/03/03/pace-studies-unveiled-sabins-4th-regional-pneumo-symposium-reinforce-n/ |title=PACE Studies Unveiled at Sabin's 4th Regional Pneumo Symposium Reinforce Need for Pneumococcal Vaccine}}</ref>
In October 2009, PACE conducted a briefing and one-on-one meetings with members of the [[European Parliament]] and [[European Commission]] to recommend action on [[Streptococcus pneumoniae|pneumococcal disease]].
On November 1â2, 2009 PACE, a member of the World Pneumonia Day Coalition, sponsored a press conference, policymaker roundtable, rally, march and symposium to commemorate [[World Pneumonia Day]] in [[Bangladesh]] where the countryâs leaders and advocates focused their attention on the prevention and treatment of [[pneumonia]]. These events and activities were led by PACE member Dr. Samir K. Saha. PACE [http://worldpneumoniaday.org/ World Pneumonia Day] events also took place in [[Brazil]], [[Dominican Republic]], [[Kenya]], [[South Africa]], the [[Czech Republic]], [[Israel]], [[Pakistan]], [[China]] and the [[Philippines]].
==Global Call to Action on Pneumococcal Disease== In 2008, PACE launched its Global Call to Action on Pneumococcal Disease Prevention<ref name="PACE Call to Action"/> in partnership with 114 professional medical societies, organizations and institutions from around the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sabin.org/advocacy-education/pace/partners |title=PACE Partners}}</ref>
==PACE Commissioned Studies== PACE commissioned two studies, ''Sequelae Due to Bacterial Meningitis among African Children: A Systematic Literature Review'',<ref name="Sequelae Due to Bacterial Meningitis among African Children">Ramakrishnan, Meenakshi, et al. (2009). [http://www.biomedcentral.com/1741-7015/7/47/abstract/ "Sequelae due to bacterial meningitis among African children: a systematic literature review"]</ref> and ''Bacterial Infections in Persons with Sickle Cell Disease: A Review of Data from Africa with a Focus on Pneumococcal Disease'',<ref name="Bacterial Infections in Persons with Sickle Cell Disease"/> that highlighted the increased risk for children in [[Africa]] of contracting [[pneumococcal disease]] and suffering its devastating consequences. It was found that African children who contract [[pneumococcal disease]] are 36 times as likely to have [[sickle-cell]] disease, a blood disorder prevalent in African children that increases the risk for infectious diseases and early death.<ref name="Sequelae Due to Bacterial Meningitis among African Children" /> Inn addition, the research showed that up to one-half of all children in [[Africa]] who get [[pneumococcal meningitis]] will either die or be disabled as a consequence of the disease, even when treated with antibiotics in a hospital. As the three leading causes of bacterial [[meningitis]] in childhood are vaccine preventable, the regular use of [[pneumococcal conjugate vaccine|conjugate vaccines]] would reduce the high burden of morbidity and mortality in both epidemic and endemic settings.<ref name="Bacterial Infections in Persons with Sickle Cell Disease" />
